thread.title: Bees stop play as South Africa claim ODI series over Sri Lanka
thread.title_full: Bees stop play as South Africa claim ODI series over Sri Lanka

title: Bees stop play as South Africa claim ODI series over Sri Lanka
text:
Bees stop play as South Africa claim ODI series over Sri Lanka Last updated 08:57, February 5 2017 GETTY IMAGES 
Players ducked for cover as the bees swarmed onto the ground. 
A fire extinguisher had to be called in after a swarm of bees stopped play during a cricket match between South Africa and Sri Lanka. 
Players ducked for cover as the angry bees swarmed onto the pitch in Johannesburg. 
Some of the swarm decided a player's helmet looked like a nice new home. GETTY IMAGES 
A groundsman tries to disperse the bees with a fire extinguisher. 
READ MORE: 
But a groundsman had other ideas, using a fire extinguisher to chase the bees away. 
South Africa eased to a seven-wicket win over Sri Lanka in the third one- day international to wrap up the series 3-0. GETTY IMAGES 
Some of the bees landed on a South African helmet. 
South Africa bowled Sri Lanka out for a modest 163 innings which amounted to only an inadequate 163 all out in 39.2 overs. 
Allrounder Dwaine Pretorius, who came into the side for Wayne Parnell claimed career-best figures of 3-19 on his return to the South Africa side SIPHIWE SIBEKO / REUTERS 
South Africa's bowler Imran Tahir is congratulated on a wicket by his captain AB de Villiers. 
Sri Lanka had made a promising start, with openers Niroshan Dickwella and Upul Tharanga putting on 60 for the first wicket but Kagiso Rabada made the breakthrough when he had Tharanga (31) caught at fine leg, and wickets fell regularly thereafter. Ad Feedback 
While Sri Lanka struggled there was no panic in South Africa's reply. 
AB de Villiers (60no) hit a 52-ball half-century to guide them to their series- sealing victory under lights with 18 overs to spare.
